content.body: othermaciej: please file bugs, i'd be happy to move words around if it helps
Hixie: will do
thanks
Hixie: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9491
othermaciej: ta
Hey guys
MikeSmith: the wording of the footer element’s example about links in footer has changed in WHATWG spec, so you might want to update nav details box
s/element’s/element/ (or more precisely the example about links in the footer)
Hixie: given this change to nav, would the defining characteristic of a group of links that warrants nav still be that they’re important enough to have a title? something else?
eg, it seems the Exampland wiki footer links could also now be nav, so wondering if this is stylistic or if there’s still a reason they’re not
hey all
JonathanNeal: what it be like
it be like this.... yo IE8 is scor'n 18/160 on html5test.com
Actually ... more like "hey guys, let's grill hotdogs tonight" "fo sho Jon" and everyone is over.
who maintains html5test.com ?
it just showed up on twitter today, afaik
Niels Niels Leenheer
magically
sounds like a fake name
Well, I accidentally wrote his first name twice, the ills of not copying and pasting.
too bad, Neils Neils is kinda catchy
I agree.
it's an anagram for "See Hell Nine Re"
which sounds much more like a real name
HTML5 will unleash the Nine Rays of Hell in 2011
the good news is that 2011 is just around the corner
one side product of public-html discussions is the innovative quoting non-conventions that people seem to come up with
Like?
e.g., http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Apr/0348.html
ME] Yes
YOU] I can make you say things now too
heh
YOU] We're releasing HTML5 this summer, so I can spend more time buying new iPhones.
ME] Wow!  Great idea, Mike.
MikeSmith: http://twitter.com/rakaz is the html5test guy.  already pinged him about some weak tests.
apparently the site's been out for a month.
funny how that happens
it does seem like a useful site I guess
even though its secret purpose is to quietly prepare for the unleashing of the Nine Rays of Hell
That is the ULTIMATE purpose!
paul_irish: is dude using modernizer at all?
nah
modernizr make that
paul_irish: I wonder why he's not
that findmebyip.com site that's gotten a lot of play does, though.
ok
theres a few things he's got i'm gonna pick up.. like output/progress/meter elements.. and undoManager
yeah, saw those
"A “Browser” is a piece of software used to access & display the Internet on your computer. ".. thanks, sensei
miketaylr: im sure you saw him fall into the chrome webforms false positive trap
ITS A TRAAAP
paul_irish: yeah
A "Browser" is a giant turtle with spikes who wants to kill Mario ... wait.
paul_irish: the Forms 2.0 detection on that site seems wacky
compares it with results at miketaylr site
miketaylr has his UI tests that are a bit better
paul_irish, what do you guys think of the ie7-js scripts Dean Edwards maintained that would add hover and type="" support to IE?  Do you think you'd ever implement stuff like that into Modernizr?
but they were necessitated because his earlier tests (same as these) did the same falsepositive shit in webkit
JonathanNeal: hover no. i'm not into parsing stylesheets. authors have been working around div:hover in ie6 forever
whats type="" support?
JonathanNeal: whatchu mean by type=""
o. what paul_irish just said
Oh, I was just talkin' about the new input types.
Oh he parsed stylesheets to add that support?  I could build something like that.
oh you mean his web forms script
i wonder if he'll ever finish that
boblet: one of the main advantages of <nav> is it lets speech readers skip navigation sections, so in footers it's not especially useful unless you want to style it
Maybe ... you guys are the experts ... I just talk a lot :)
nav++
I wonder why nobody has written a change proposal for removing nav
miketaylr: oh shittttt whoa.. http://code.google.com/p/webforms2/ our buddies weston and zoltan have been hacking on that too
wow
ahh cool. i showed that to weston a while back
back when dean told me "it's beta, please don't blog about it" :/
did they actually implement the repetition model too?
oh wait, no sorry. this is weston's old one
Hixie: unless you wanted to access those links I guess
MikeSmith: http://sourceforge.net/projects/wf2/forums/forum/466583/topic/1604767?message=3994714 looks like it?
boblet: yeah, but who ever uses footer navigation links?
paul_irish: hmm, yeah, 2006
i mean, if they were meant for common use, they'd be up front
well, the Emperor of Exampland, for one
afaik, weston hasn't touched this in years
Hixie: I’m still fuzzy on what is and isn’t a major (née primary) navigation block though. the previous “footer links wouldn’t qualify b/c they’re random” was informative, but that’s gone now
only the author can know what's major and what isn't
MikeSmith: the wording of the example about links in footer in the nav element has changed in WHATWG spec, so you might want to update nav details box
Hixie: sounds koan-y. me likes
I still think it would be useful to have a standard way to distinguish primary navigation from secondary navigation
primary navigation is first? :-)
in document order? it could be last if the author wants to, and use CSS to position it
seriously, the main distinction that most designers seem to make is between primary and secondary nav
if you look at class values and such in more granularity
but wtfu do I know anyway
I'm not a designer
and don't want to be
CSS is just to frustrating
*too
traditionally the hardcore standardista is content then site nav, but with the state of CSS positioning (…implementations) it pretty much always ends up being nav then content
s/standardista/standardista approach/
MikeSmith: CSS is great, it’s just the implementations that are … frustrating
I guess we will know more after nav gets used -- I'd expect to see a lot of <nav class=primary> and <nav class=secondary> and such
boblet: same could be said about many features of the web platform
it's all great until you actually try to use it
given ppl who care about such things generally add skip links, that could be used as a designator of primary nav
generally only one “skip to nav” link, even if there are multiple things that could be marked up with nav
(although I’ve seen “skip to search”)
Hixie: trying to implement http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/text-level-semantics.html#guidance-for-conformance-checkers is giving me heartburn, man
I really need to chat with hsivonen
boblet- Why should content be first than navigation? Sorry, I'm kind of new to this Web development topic.

KaOSoFt: the idea is that for content pages (ie not the homepage or the archives etc) the user generally wants to get to the content. For text-to-speech reading through the navigation and other stuff in the header takes time (visual equivalent is Flash loading animation)
KaOSoFt: hence skip to content links and putting nav after content in HTML (which as mentioned is generally a massive pita)
boblet- Hmmm, "content pages". I get it. Thanks. :)
KaOSoFt: happy to help :)
MikeSmith: have you found any of the conditions hard other than the paragraph/section one?
othermaciej: the figcaption exception is PITA, though not really hard I suppose
the fact that that you the figcaption can occur before or after the img in document order
so have to hold off on that check until endelement event for the figure element
MikeSmith: I was gonna say - you could track that you are in a figure
yeah
we just don't have a similar case like this yet to steal from
in the existing code
we will after this, though, I guess
though I hope we won't be needing any more of this kind of stuff
yeah I don't know what other requirements might be like this
hopefully none
because from where I sit, it's pretty much an anti-pattern for conformance criteria
*for document-conformance criteria
it's also a challenge to try to figure out how to provide a concise error message for this set of cases
or impossible
I think the only practical thing to do is to provide a link to some document that provides detailed guidance
e.g., as with the "Use CSS instead" link we have now
MikeSmith: I would describe the error as just missing alt
yeah
MikeSmith: then briefly mention there are some other alternatives for describing an image and link to the list
I think "element img is missing required attribute alt" is just about all the error message itself can say
really, there's no ability to give anything more descriptive for a missing attribute?
yeah, there is
it can add what you just described
ok, good
I found a lot of suboptimal error messages during the conformance study, at some point I should be a good citizen and file more validator bugs
what I meant is, just the description of what the actual error is, I don't know what else to have it say
some of those I have fixed already
ah, right, as a short description, I think that is fine
yeah, I've seen some of your fixes going by
anyway - that's a mostly accurate description of the error, even though there are a few exemptions to the alt requirement
right
heyo
MikeSmith: file bugs
othermaciej: any suggestions for a shorter term than "valid URL potentially surrounded by spaces"?
Hixie: "valid URL attribute value" is a little shorter (assuming that is equally accurate)
or even just "URL attribute value" if there is no need for the non-valid version
i'd rather not call the syntax by where it's used
that always ends up giving me trouble later when i reuse the syntaxes
"space-delimited URL"
i'll just go with potentially surrounded by spaces, it's less ambiguous
it does seem like a pretty unambiguous choice
me tries to figure out which way the wind blowing on adding presence of role=presentation as an exception to the alt-required constraint
morning good chaps & ladies.
if it is favorable I could add it speculatively/experimentally now to the checker in the interest of giving something broader to test against
or I could hold off and just do it for now as close to the existing spec as I can get
micheil: hey
MikeSmith: if it weren't for the variations in spellings, we'd have the same first/last names.
your first name has a (tm) in it also?
MikeSmith: the role=presentation exception is pointless... it's longer than the alternative (just writing alt="", which implied role=presentation automatically)
s/implied/implies/
MikeSmith: ah, no.
MikeSmith: besides, mine's more trademarkable
Hixie: OK
hey, Hixie thanks for the slight tip last night on where to look for the protocol details on websockets, so far I've got the server accepting clients and reading the headers
cool
micheil: your parents clearly have more imagination than mine
Hixie: how about aria-labelledby ?
Hixie: I've been working from a slightly different use case, so far all the server's I've seen don't make use of the path in the initial GET request
is it intended to be used?
MikeSmith: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6496
MikeSmith: yes
er
micheil: yes
Hixie: cool, do you know of any other servers they make use of it?
micheil: i wrote one that does, but it's a hack :-) (i used it to smuggle in the username/password of the user, instead of sending it in the first frame)
so far most I've seen don't even parse the headers correctly
yeah
because, theoretically there aren't any headers not allowed
plus, they use a fixed order for them, which isn't correct
that's why the latest draft requires the servers to parse two headers, because otherwise the servers wouldn't parse any and would be vulnerable to a cross-protocol attack from HTTP
Hixie: I see, thanks (about aria-labelledby)
two headers? I've missed that one.. I'll have to check up on it
the two Sec-WebSocket-Key headers
MikeSmith: as a general rule, ARIA is a layer above HTML, so it should be possible to take any HTML file with ARIA, remove all the ARIA, and not make the page less conforming
oh, I thought they were part of the first GET request
micheil: they are
micheil: by "header" i meant "field" in websocket terminology, my bad
okay
Hixie: yeah, that does seems rational, thanks
ouch. Tony Ross misdescribed the fallback mechanism of <video> at MIX.
claiming that the fallback content is rendered if the codec isn't available
I wonder if they've implemented it that way in IE9
and I wonder how many MIX10 visitors will now assume they can rely on the described behavior
hsivonen: are you going to around still in a couple hours from now?
I really want to talk with you when you have time
but I need to head out for a bit first
Hixie: good lordy is that spec on WebSockets very complete with all basis covered..
Hixie++
Hixie: also, with the usage of read 8 bytes from the server/client, I've found an ambiguity: if it's in UTF8, 8 bytes would be variable
it may be 8 characters or it could be four
micheil: the random bytes only use characters in the ascii range
ah
micheil: it need not be characters at all
so, in which case the characters would have a string length of 8
+utf8
micheil: It is better to think of it as a bytearray of length 8
Dunno is node.js supports that
not sure I have access to bytearray types
concept
considering it's js
Right
Hopefully soon
js--
If the TC39 people pull their finger out a little
gsnedders: js++*Infinity.
(it looks like WebGL will force the issue though)
I'm sorry, GWT has made me hate JS forever.
Anyway, the point is that in a sensible languge (note: very few such languages exist) that makes a clear distinction between a string and a sequence of bytes
gsnedders: GWT's mainly java though
micheil: The JS it generates is horrid.
you would treat the random bytes as bytes, not as a string
yeah, I'm not generating JS, I'm writing it.
gsnedders: Presumably the anyone feels the same way debugging generated bytecode
well, I do have a byte buffer that I could use (interfaces with C), but that may be a little heavy
hopes the byte array issue gets resolved before any browser ships a release version with WebGL enabled
seriosuly thinks it would help to replace all the variable names in GWT code with random english words
But feels that eval might screw things up
(the idea being it is easier to figure out what is going on if you can say that "sheep calls confuse which calls ancilliary" rather than "xzy calls dfg which calls ijk"
it's sure nicer to figure out what GWT is doing if you possess the original Java source and can recompile without minification
what bits of Google Wave are open source?
is any of the front end GWT stuff Open Source?
annevk: i think it would be awesome if the top five hundred or so websites in each country were accessible
wonders what metric you are using for top 500
is quoting annevk's blog
I mean quite a few of those are probably porn. DO you get accessible porn?
it would be awesome
So, the alt text for images is just erotic writing instead of the pictures?
what about video?
Yeah, I guess a transcript wouldn't help much
zcorpan, yeah, maybe I should have lowered the number, wasn't sure
http://diveintomark.org/archives/2006/07/27/imagination
hsivonen: I didn't dount that there sould be a demand for accessible porn
Well I did obviously
But I didn't mean to
I meant to doubt that it would be an alternative presentation of other porn
rather than a totally different resource
s/sould/would/
s/dount/doubt/
You know I read that several times and didn't notice that I had totally misspelt the key word in the sentence
now http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-archive/2010Apr/0039.html (Member-only) is interesting
finally some hidden agenda gossip
hmm.. what would be an example of the /resource name/ for a websocket on the server?
morning there jeremy (adactio)
Morning.
micheil: Presumably it can be anything you want
hmm..
okay
It is just an opaque string that gets used by the server however it choses
it's definition seems rather ambiguous, I don't know if it should be clarified (/cc Hixie )
under the definition, it states that it should be the resource given in the clients handshake, then there's two blank lines and something about True / False if encrypted
True if the connection is encrypted or if the server expected it to be encrypted; false otherwise.
The two blank lines sound like they should be talking about the secure flag
What document are you reading?
ok now someone needs to test for canvas bugs in flash cs5
hmm, I meant W3C Member-only above...
annevk: What other type of Member could you have meant?
whatwg Member I guess
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-socket-protocol/
same is present in the latest draft: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hixie-thewebsocketprotocol-75#section-5.1
-75 and and the whatwg.org version are different
on may be more up-to-date
whatwg.org is
but the problem is present from about -67 onwards

If you have a trunk gecko or webkit based browser to hand (or maybe even lynx or something) I seriously recommend using http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete.html?slow-browser=1#network
It is always the latest version and you can link to any part you are having trouble with
that is hella slow, but anyway :)
I think, but without complete certianty, that the slow-browser thing stops some scripts from running
which makes it faster
(but that might just be the main spec or I might have forgotten the right parameter name)
jgraham: ?slow-browser is right
hmm.. I suppose rather then setting my key_1 & key_2 to be the values of the two Sec-WebSocket_Key[1|2] fields, I should just set them to be the numbers, as that's all that's actually used, isn't it?
no, actually that's wrong.
the numbers and the number of spaces are used
yeah
I might have to make that a sub-method..
bbl. dinner
thanks for the help folks :)
hmm wonder if it's problematic if the client inserts the spaces at the start or at the end of the string
not if you have a WebSocket server
but if you do both HTTP and WebSocket you need some kind of switching before continuing parsing
or raw buffer access or something I suppose
annevk: the solution is to make proper use of the upgrade / connection headers
so if you are an HTTP server you parse the first bit as HTTP until you hit the upgrade header at which point you continue parsing using a WebSocket parser?
yeah
FWIW I think assuming HTTP servers have a particular architecture is probably a bad idea
including an architecture required to conform to the spec
(HTTP spec that is)
jgraham: true, hence the reason I'm implementing my node websocket server on top of raw network sockets
Especially for little-used features
or something like that
micheil: Right but from the point of view of websockets it means we should be wary of security features that might fail due to likely bugs in servers
(i.e. I agree with zcorpan about the location of the spaces)
and then the headers are going to be separated as {key}: {value}\r\n
and according to the spec for websockets, you should be fine, however, I wouldn't think of sticking websockets and a httpserver on the same network process
(ie, reading from the same stream of data)
Me neither but some people seem to want that
Or something
you do two processes
different ports
eg, your webserver on *.host.tld:80, and then your websockets on say, ws.host.tld:80
or just host:80 for http, host:8080 for websockets

nothing actually stops the two network sockets from talking to each other, depending on how you architect your app, take PusherApp.com for example, they have a rails app somehow pushing data onto a websocket server
jgraham, requiring a WebSocket server to understand HTTP semantics is also bad
jgraham, same for a WebSocket client
annevk: there needs to be some form of handshaking, and if that's done over upgrade, so be it.
annevk: It doesn't have to at the moment, really
It just has to follow the spec
as far as I'm concerned, I'll leave the spec writing to the guys who are the computer scientists or know what they're doing. I'm just interested in implementing and using things to the spec.
micheil: the spec likely has a number of bugs. if you're implementing it, you might catch bugs as you go, and it'd be really useful if you sent comments about your findings
yeah
I will do, so far I've only had issues with wording on it
cool
wonders how many people are actually Computer Scientists by training. I mean I know Hixie isn't (I know a few people are but most people I just have no idea)
jgraham: Hixie isn't? I always had the impression that a lot of the guys on the w3c board / the spec writers were computer scientists and things like that
and I'm sure if you asked most web developers, they'd think the same
raise hands, everyone, who are computer scientists?
What's a computer scientist? Someone who theorizes about computer stuff?
jgraham, indeed, that's a good thing
did 1 year of something akin to CS and then just quit uni altogether
asmodai: that's one thing
jgraham, but it does assume HTTP server architecture that also want to implement WebSocket can deal with that
has a CS degree
although I'm still at uni, so....
has a CS masters
is one of those autodidact scary types
I wouldn't say I'm a computer scientist though
has an IT degree, which AIUI, is basically the same as a CS degree, but had a different name at my university.
CS is more about research into areas of computing more than actual software development
I've so far done.. 1 subject in a computer science degree.. but that's only because I can't do studies fulltime with highschool still on
and I'd say the majority of CS courses and CS professors couldn't program for toffee
wonders how a course would program
jgraham: bad phrasing there
CS courses don't tend to teach people how to program
they teach students some programming languages, and then it's pretty much ignored
workmad3, do they teach more about hardware aspects of computing?
pretty much
like processor architectures, etc?
although in the course I TA, I do make it a point to beat in good coding practices
Lachy: some do, or they'll teach things things like language design principles, or automated program and theorem proving, or lots of advanced db theory
will be taking Advanced Algorithm theory, compiler theory, and ethics as CS courses next semester

but (mine at least) stopped on the programming front at the point of 'you can churn out some basic code now, you're a programmer'... no use of VCS, no code design or architecture, basically nothing to make a decent software engineer
notes that the theoretical CS courses seem the most interesting / useful
(but that could be my bias)
my IT course covered a range of subjects including Java, C++, HTML/CSS/JS, databases and SQL, with little bits about hardware
well, given the scope of a project in a class, using VCS is pretty much overkill
also covered things like project development and management
(because you can pretty easilly lean to program by programming but learning, say, analysis of complex algorithsm on your own is pretty hard)
that's rather confusing.. in that complete work webapp thing, the numbering of sections is totally different to in the IEFT drafts
I think the largest one I managed to hit was 1K lines in magnitude
jcranmer: if it's over about 100 LoC, I'd want it in a VCS now
although I'd probably use git and just keep it local admittedly :)
lemme rephrase... it's one or two files, essentially
workmad3: what, you mean you don't work like a designer? myclass.final.12.final.proposal.png
:P
VCS comes into play when either a) I want to publish it or b) it's too complex that changing a file or three at a time stops working
micheil: heh :)
wonders if the whatwg specs are in a git repo..
jcranmer: for me, VCS comes into play when a) I want to do some code
micheil: svn I believe
workmad3: wuss :-)
it's just a standard thing to do for me now... especially with how easy it is to just create a git repo for it
hmm.. public?
VCS and so on seem like practical skills that are really easy to pick up
Kinda like a physics degree teaching you how to solder
what's physics got to do with soldering?
(although I admit I am hopeless at soldering and when I had to do that in my physics degree I made a total mess of it)
jgraham: there were people on electrical engineering course at my uni in the third year who couldn't solder
micheil: http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker
workmad3: I didn't say engineering on purpose
jcranmer: neat
jgraham: my view personally is that if a uni course is claiming to teach programming, then they should teach the good habits that go with it
anyway, I need to go get lunch
-20 points: used #include "mylib.c"

(the rather strained analogy I was trying to make is that soldering is often a required skill for practising physicists. But the point of the degree is to make sure that you know about quantum machanics and relativity and ways of thinking about solving problems like a physicist, not about how to solder)
-100 points: code doesn't compile due to cyclic include structure (WTF?)

hmm.. with the ASCII case-insensitive comparing, would an implementor be expected to convert from UTF8 to ASCII to compare, or would change the variable value to lowercase and checking it against another value that is lowercase be sufficient?
micheil: It is defined somewhere, but it basically means change ACSII uppercase to ASCII lowercase and leave all other characters untouched
yeah
so equivilant to javascripts string.toLowerCase
That does Unicode lowercasing, I thought
uhh.. I'm not sure
Yes, not equivalent, for the reasons Philip gave
You just want tr/A-Z/a-z/ (or whatever the syntax is)
hmm..
yeah, so, I'd probably have to use regex, and then use a callback on it
or you could map A-Z to a-z and then compare
huh?
but if you implement in JS I guess regexp might be faster
yeah, I think so

oh, wait, not a bug

right

bitwise vs standard

yeah

(I <3 the ES spec)
it's surprising how many people are implementing websocket servers wrongly

I expect they are implementing the old spec
not that greatly though
or rather implemented
in the sense that they are using fixed header fields and very fixed input

ah, fair enough

wonders what made Hixie change his mind
was arguing that within a few months of him spec'ing out the original WS draft
I wouldn't want websockets on top of http.
http has a fair bit of extra data baggage, compared with a raw tcp socket

and then finally you get dumped by your SO for spending too much time on the internet, become depressed and die

AryehGregor: hyatt no longer an editor
So the next WD won't list him as an editor?
needs a source to cite to revert http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=HTML5&diff=355515922&oldid=355096550
suspects linking to the SVN logs would be considered "original research"
Indeed not
Do you know of anywhere this is written down that I can cite?
